Event.name: Communication_manner
Event.definition:
<def-root>The words in this frame describe <fen>Manner</fen>s of verbal communication. All of them can occur with quoted expressions.
<ex><fex name="Speaker">He</fex> <t>slurred</t> <fex name="Message">his confession</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Speaker
Arg.definition: <def-root>Speaker is the sentient entity that produces a Message or communicates about a Topic. It is expressed as the External Argument of verbs: <ex><fex name="Speaker">The boy</fex> <t>mumbled</t> an apology. </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Addressee
Arg.definition: <def-root>Addressee is the person to whom the Speaker is communicating. When expressed, the Addressee occurs as a PP Complement: <ex>The taxi driver <t>chattered</t> away <fex name="Addressee">to me</fex> about gardening. </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Message
Arg.definition: <def-root>Message is the content which is communicated by the Speaker. The Message may be a direct quote, a finite complement clause or an NP Object: <ex><fex name="Message">"I- It was an accident,"</fex> Jo <t>stammered</t>.</ex> <ex> Jo <t>stammered</t> <fex name="Message">that it was an accident</fex>.</ex> <ex> Jo <t>stammered</t> <fex name="Message">an apology</fex>. </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Topic
Arg.definition: <def-root>Topic is the subject matter of the communicated Message. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>about</ment> and, in this frame, is frequently preceded by a quantificational noun which is treated as referring to the Message: <ex>The actor <t>chattered</t> <fex name="Topic">about the difficulties of being famous</fex>.</ex> <ex>The person next to me <t>muttered</t> something <fex name="Topic">about pride coming before a fall</fex>. </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Medium
Arg.definition: <def-root>This frame element expresses the medium of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the Message occurs. It is normally expressed as a PP-complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>: <ex>The Beatles <t>sang</t> <fex name="Medium">on the Ed Sullivan show</fex>.</ex> <ex>The drunk man <t>mumbled</t> <fex name="Medium">in French</fex>. </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Depictive
Arg.definition: <def-root><fen>Depictive</fen> is used for any phrase describing a participant in an action. <ex>Jo <t>babbled</t> <fex name="Depictive">in a tuxedo</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Degree
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Degree</fen> to which an event occurs.</def-root>

Arg.name: Result
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Result</fen> of an event.</def-root>

Arg.name: Back
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates that the communication act denoted by the target is in response to an earlier communication act in which the roles of <fen>Speaker</fen> and <fen>Addressee</fen> were reversed. This is conceptually akin to the Communication_response frame in which the targets themselves denote the responsive nature of the act.</def-root>

Arg.name: Duration
Arg.definition: <def-root>The amount of time that the communicative event lasts.</def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition: <def-root>The time at which the communication event takes place.</def-root>

Arg.name: Place
Arg.definition: <def-root>The location at which the communication event takes place.</def-root>

Arg.name: Means
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The action that the <fen>Speaker</fen> performs in order to communicate in the particular way described by the target.
<ex>She could only <t>sing</t> along <fex name="mea">by watching others singing</fex>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: babble.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk rapidly and continuously in a foolish, excited, or incomprehensible way

lexUnit.name: bluster.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk in a loud, aggressive, or indignant way with little effect

lexUnit.name: chant.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: say or shout repeatedly in a sing-song tone

lexUnit.name: chatter.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk rapidly or incessantly about trivial matters

lexUnit.name: drawl.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak in a slow, lazy way with prolonged vowel sounds

lexUnit.name: gabble.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk rapidly and unintelligibly.

lexUnit.name: gibber.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak rapidly and unintelligibly, typically through fear or shock.

lexUnit.name: jabber.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk rapidly and excitedly but with little sense.

lexUnit.name: lisp.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: to speak in a manner in which 's' is pronounced like 'th' in 'thick' and 'z' is pronounced like 'th' in 'this'

lexUnit.name: mouth.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: say (something) in an insincere or pompous way

lexUnit.name: mumble.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: say something indistinctly and quietly.

lexUnit.name: mutter.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: say in a barely audible voice.

lexUnit.name: natter.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: chat casually.

lexUnit.name: prattle.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk at length in a foolish or inconsequential way.

lexUnit.name: rant.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak or shout at length in a wild, impassioned way.

lexUnit.name: rave.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk wildly or incoherently.

lexUnit.name: shout.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak or call out very loudly.

lexUnit.name: simper.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to speak with a silly, self-conscious, coy smile.

lexUnit.name: sing.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: make musical sounds with the voice, especially words with a set tune.

lexUnit.name: slur.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: speak or articulate speech indistinctly.

lexUnit.name: stammer.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak with sudden involuntary pauses and a tendency to repeat the initial letters of words.

lexUnit.name: stutter.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: talk with continued involuntary repetition of sounds, especially initial consonants.

lexUnit.name: whisper.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: speak very softly using one's breath rather than one's throat.

lexUnit.name: blabber.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to speak foolishly or excessively
